Subject: Short note on squared error
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770077; y=rZZyr7lGci73npZuqKYL8xvakfEQWRQxzdA5UKqlWJWGaymqetJb
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod

SharpNEAT's XOR and multiplexer domains currently have fitness metrics
based on absolute error, modifying them to punish squared error
produces a noticable improvement in # of generations to find a
solution. Fairly obvious I guess but I thought it was worth
mentioning.

I was looking at these domains again in particular because I'm about
to use them to test use of radial basis functions (new to SharpNEAT)
and these are good examples of 'fractured' domains that are possibly
conducive to solution by RBF networks.

And as a final note, 11-multiplexer is still a pretty hard problem for
NEAT so it's going to be interesting to see how RBF-NEAT performs on
this metric in particular.

Colin.
